conclusion: Determine the time at which the laser beam emerges from the arc surface ABC of the semi-cylindrical transparent brick.
The semi-cylindrical brick has a radius r, and its center is O. The endpoints of the diameter are A (top) and C (bottom).
The laser beam starts at A and moves uniformly along the diameter AC with a speed v.
At any given moment, the laser beam enters the brick at a point D along AC, and refracts inside the brick due to the change in medium (air to transparent material).
When the laser beam enters the transparent brick at D, it refracts and travels toward the curved arc surface ABC.
The laser beam emerges from the arc surface at a point determined by the geometry of the brick and the refractive index n.
The laser beam enters the brick at D, which is at a distance x from A along AC. The position x is given by x = vt where t is the time elapsed since the laser beam started moving.
The angle of incidence θ at point D is determined by the geometry of the brick. The laser beam travels toward the center O, forming a triangle △AOD.
Using trigonometry, the angle θ is given by sinθ = x/r where r is the radius of the semi-cylindrical brick.

The laser beam emerges from the arc surface ABC when it reaches the farthest point B on the curved surface. At this point, the beam has traveled through the brick and reached the edge of the semi-circle.
The farthest point B corresponds to the angle θ = 90°, because the beam has traveled from D to the edge of the semi-circle.
From the relationship sinθ = x/r, we know sinθ = 1 (at θ = 90°).
Substituting sinθ = x/r, we find x = r.
Since x = vt, we can solve for t: t = r/v.
The time at which the laser beam emerges from the arc surface ABC is t = r/v.
